document: The call was made at a scrutiny meeting of the council to discuss the problems surrounding the new vessel.Council leader Dave Stewart said the crossing at Cowes would be free until 2 July "in recognition of the problems" and to allow feedback.Mr Stewart said the council had ordered a review of the project by auditors.He said it had been a "frustrating and disappointing start" to the ferry.Since launching late on 14 May the chain ferry has broken down, run aground and been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to "training issues".Cars have also been damaged getting on and off.Shopkeeper Angie Booth, who owns Valu-4-U in East Cowes, said: "Whether I come out of this and survive I am not sure - other businesses too. We are bearing the brunt of the loss of almost six months of trade."Will you compensate local businesses, the same as for damaged cars?"Transport councillor Ian Ward said compensation was up for discussion.He added: "I don't think it's a disaster. It's a prototype. There are bound to be teething problems. There were electrical problems which the company has rectified."He said the council authorised the manufacture of ramp extensions to resolve the problem of vehicles scraping the concrete.He said groundings were an issue with seamanship, which had been resolved.
claim: businesses and businesses on the isle of wight are to be allowed to free up the new chain ferry, the council has said.
doc_sents: The call was made at a scrutiny meeting of the council to discuss the problems surrounding the new vessel.
Council leader Dave Stewart said the crossing at Cowes would be free until 2 July "in recognition of the problems" and to allow feedback.
Mr Stewart said the council had ordered a review of the project by auditors.
He said it had been a "frustrating and disappointing start" to the ferry.
Since launching late on 14 May the chain ferry has broken down, run aground and been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to "training issues".
Cars have also been damaged getting on and off.
Shopkeeper Angie Booth, who owns Valu-4-U in East Cowes, said: "Whether I come out of this and survive I am not sure - other businesses too.
We are bearing the brunt of the loss of almost six months of trade.
"Will you compensate local businesses, the same as for damaged cars?"Transport
councillor Ian Ward said compensation was up for discussion.
He added: "I don't think it's a disaster.
There are bound to be teething problems.
There were electrical problems which the company has rectified.
"He said the council authorised the manufacture of ramp extensions to resolve the problem of vehicles scraping the concrete.
He said groundings were an issue with seamanship, which had been resolved.
sum_sents: businesses and businesses on the isle of wight are to be allowed to free up the new chain ferry, the council has said.

Therefore, the answer is yes, the summary is consistent with the article.

2. The article mentions that the ferry has broken down, run aground, and been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to "training issues". This indicates that there have been significant problems with the ferry's operation.
3. The article quotes a shopkeeper who expresses concern about the impact of the ferry's problems on her business, and asks if the council will compensate local businesses for their losses. This suggests that the ferry's issues are having a real-world impact on local businesses.
4. The article states that the council leader has announced that the crossing at Cowes will be free until 2 July "in recognition of the problems" and to allow feedback. This suggests that the council is taking steps to address the issues and is willing to provide some relief to affected businesses and residents.

Based on these points, it seems that the summary is not consistent with the article. The summary only mentions that businesses will be allowed to use the ferry for free, but it does not mention the significant problems with the ferry's operation or the council's efforts to address these issues. Therefore, the answer is no, the summary is not consistent with the article.
